thread.title: Disney holiday dining

author: The Telegraph
title: Disney holiday dining
text: Meals shared with family and friends are the stuff of holiday memories. They bring everyone together to experience great food while you excitedly chatter about the highlights of your day. With Disney holidays, the memories take on a whole new dimension; there’s so much dining choice and the quality is exceptional. Even the fussiest of eaters will find something they love, thanks to the amazing array of experiences, world cuisines and styles of eateries. Soak up the elegance of Victoria and Albert’s, where fine dining and opulent décor collide to create a beautifully stylish evening On Disney’s cruise ships variety is the spice of life. There are three main family dining rooms and for guests to rotate around so you can enjoy a different experience each evening. And they are certainly very impressive. Children will be transfixed by the Animator’s Palace, where sketches on the walls come to life and turn into moving animations. Children will be transfixed by the Animator’s Palate, where sketches on the walls come to life and turn into moving animations. The conservatory-style Enchanted Garden on board Disney Dream and Disney Fantasy, with its frescos and seven-foot-high fountain, is another favourite. Menu choices embrace the world, from Pan-Asian to French, and from Caribbean to home-style American. And there are always special children’s choices. While your seating location may change, your serving staff will not, ensuring you see the same familiar smiles as you try out different cuisines. Magnificent buffet breakfasts plus waiter-served lunches are available in these restaurants, too. Cheers: adults-only restaurant Palo provides a relaxing escape On board Disney Dream, eat like a king or queen at the Royal Palace restaurant, serving French cuisine and inspired by Sleeping Beauty, Snow White, Cinderella and Beauty and the Beast. Grown-ups will love the sophistication of Palo, the adults-only restaurant where stylish Italian cuisine meets grand ocean views. But that’s only half the story. Dotted around the ships are half a dozen other eating places, where you can opt to for main meals as well as find snacks, fresh fruit, salads and ice creams. You could eat beneath a shady awning high on deck with nothing but ocean around you, or you could put on your glam gear and dine amidst soft lights and crisp table linen in one of the adult-only restaurants. And if you get a yearning for a chocolate-chip muffin or a BLT in the middle of the night, there’s 24-hour room service. The variety doesn’t stop on land. You can eat in a different place for every meal of your holiday when staying at Walt Disney World. With more than 100 restaurants, there is no danger of anyone going hungry, and every fussy eater is catered for. The food truly spans the globe, from Asian to Cajun, Norwegian to Moroccan, as well as the more typical Mediterranean, American and British. As if the top-notch food wasn’t enough, you could even be joined by your favourite character. Whether it’s breakfast, dinner or a fun-filled afternoon tea, 1900 Park Fare at Disney’s Grand Floridian Resort & Spa is the place to be. Fine dining: enjoy Italian cuisine and ocean views at adults-only Palo At the Supercalifragilistic Breakfast, Mary Poppins, The Mad Hatter or Alice in Wonderland could all pop in for pancakes and Mickey-shaped waffles. The Wonderland Tea Party features favourite characters, while Cinderella and Prince Charming host the Happily Ever After Dinner. Grown-ups will enjoy sitting outside in a German beer garden listening to a traditional oompah band or dining in a stylish Cuban café at Paradiso 37. For fine dining, try Cítrico’s at Disney’s Grand Floridian Resort Hotel, where you can enjoy a multi-course, wine-paired dinner with personal attention from the chef, and even look out over the fireworks spectacular in Magic Kingdom. How about dinner and a show? The Hoop Dee-Doo Musical Revue provides a great country feast accompanied by a high-spirited hootenanny, while at ’Ohana, you can sit beneath tropical tikis as waiters deliver Hawaiian specialities such as oak-grilled shrimps and skewered chicken; hula-hoops and Hawaiian dancing are an optional extra. Dine underwater (almost) in the Coral Reef Restaurant where tables nestle next to huge windows looking into a coral reef aquarium teeming with turtles, rays and sharks. Children will love T-REX for dinosaur-themed dining, surrounded by prehistoric creatures. The fun and frolics continue even at simple cafés and snack bars. At Prime Time, for instance, you can eat classic American comfort food in a Fifties-style diner, while at the slick and shiny Contempo Café waiters are replaced by touch screens. California Grill: serving up spectacular views with gourmet dining Tasty African street food can be ordered at Harambe Market, a dusty-looking colonial-style building overlooked by an iconic water tower. Place your order then sit back under a shady tree. Looking for something sophisticated? Savour the best of Pacific coast fare on the 15th floor of Disney’s Contemporary Resort, where the California Grill serves up spectacular views with gourmet dining. Soak up the Victorian elegance of Victoria and Albert’s, where fine dining and opulent décor collide to create a beautifully stylish evening. Or travel to New England via the Yachtsman Steakhouse for fresh seafood and juicy steaks. But nothing beats dining with Mickey and his friends. Cinderella glides between the tables at the medieval-style Cinderella’s Royal Table banquet hall. Chip ‘n’ Dale are likely to drop by at the revolving Garden Grill Restaurant, which specialises in rustic American food – and with many of the vegetables grown in Epcot Park’s own greenhouses. And make sure to reserve a table at Chef Mickey’s, a huge, fun, all-you-can-eat buffet – you can even customise your own desserts – where Mickey and a host of pals will come and play merry havoc. • Find out more about Disney Cruises, Disney holidays and Walt Disney World
